step1.sentence: Don't get ahead of yourself — we haven't even finished the first round of interviews yet.

step2.story: Mina was so excited after her first coding bootcamp session that she started telling everyone she'd be a senior developer by summer. Her mentor smiled and said, "I love your enthusiasm, but don't get ahead of yourself — there's still a lot to learn." Mina laughed and promised to take it one step at a time.

step3.story: Jason had only been at the startup for two weeks, but he was already drafting a proposal to restructure the entire engineering team. He stayed up late polishing his slides, imagining himself presenting to the CEO. The next morning, his team lead pulled him aside. "I can see you're ambitious, and that's great," she said, "but you're getting ahead of yourself. You don't even know how our deployment pipeline works yet." Jason felt his cheeks flush. He realized he'd been so focused on making a big impression that he'd skipped the basics. He closed the slide deck, opened the onboarding docs, and decided to earn his credibility the hard way.

meaning.literalMeaningKo: 자기 자신보다 앞서 나가다, 즉 아직 준비되지 않은 단계로 성급하게 뛰어드는 것을 의미합니다.
meaning.realUsageKo: 아직 기본적인 것도 안 된 상태에서 결과나 다음 단계를 너무 일찍 생각할 때 사용합니다. '김칫국부터 마시지 마라'와 비슷한 맥락으로, 현실적인 순서를 무시하고 성급하게 행동하는 사람에게 충고할 때 자주 씁니다.
meaning.etymologyKo: 물리적으로 자기 몸보다 앞서 나가면 균형을 잃고 넘어지는 모습에서 유래했습니다. 19세기부터 비유적 표현으로 쓰이기 시작했습니다.
meaning.nuanceKo: 부정적인 비판보다는 친근한 충고나 경고의 뉘앙스가 강합니다. 주로 'Don't get ahead of yourself'처럼 부정형으로 사용되며, 상대방의 의욕은 인정하되 현실감각을 일깨워줄 때 씁니다.
meaning.shortExampleEn: You're getting ahead of yourself — let's finish planning before we start buying supplies.
meaning.shortExampleKo: 너무 앞서가지 마 — 물건 사기 전에 계획부터 끝내자.
